venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Learn how to prepare and alter clay. (Held at Wellington Potters' Association, 130 Grant Road, Thorndon).

Learn how to prepare and alter clay: pinch, coil, slab, extruder and roller use. Understand shrinkage and clay care, joining techniques, drape and press moulding, mark making, slip making and application - as well as tetrahedron, cone and cylinder production

The techniques learnt during the making will provide an excellent springboard to creating a wide array of ceramic objects in the future.

The emphasis will be on learning techniques and honing those skills and by the end of the 8 sessions you will have completed three works which will be fired and glazed.

Pottery courses are held at Wellington Potters' Association, 130 Grant Road, Thorndon. All our courses are scheduled up to a year in advance which means the at times we may need to make changes to the original schedule. Please make sure you check your emails regularly in case of any changes.

id: Writers on Mondays: Jennifer Trevelyan and Jenny Pattrick-Te Marae, Te Papa Tongarewa, 55 Cable Street, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Writers on Mondays: Jennifer Trevelyan and Jenny Pattrick
venue: Te Marae, Te Papa Tongarewa, 55 Cable Street, Wellington
description:
HIGH TIDE: JENNIFER TREVELYAN AND JENNY PATTRICK
Seasoned Wellington writer Jenny Pattrick’s latest novel, Sea Change, digs into the developing tensions within a small Kāpiti Coast community forced to negotiate a managed retreat after a rupture in the Alpine fault generates a devastating tsunami. Tensions of a different kind propel debut author Jennifer Trevelyan’s A Beautiful Family. This suspenseful coming-of-age novel turns around a summer holiday on the coast and the search for a missing girl. Two authors at different stages of their careers discuss their work with Kate Duignan.

ADMISSION IS FREE—ALL WELCOME
Writers on Mondays is presented with the Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa, Circa Theatre, Meow and Phantom Billstickers National Poetry Day and supported by the Letteri Family.

id: Natural Textured Rings-Workspace Ōtaki, 6 Hewson Crescent, Ōtaki-Event Finder
name: Natural Textured Rings
venue: Workspace Ōtaki, 6 Hewson Crescent, Ōtaki
description:
Make your own personalised ring - a gift for yourself or someone special! :-)

Learn the basic technique first in copper or brass, and then craft your final piece in silver!

Over this taster class, you’ll be guided through the process of heating and texturing metal, cutting and shaping with traditional jewellery tools. Use feathers, leaves, or fabrics to create a unique texture for a beautiful ring!

Learn to measure your finger, cut metal to length and texture it without rolling mill, hammers and punches. Then use a jewellers torch, sandpaper and polishing, and your beautiful new ring will be ready to wear.

This 3-hour class is ideal for beginners, groups of friends and visitors to the city.

Included in the class fee are copper and brass for practising on, a sterling silver ring strip and all consumables such as sandpaper, solder and chemicals. Extra metals are available for purchase in the studio.

Kids aged 12 (or so) are welcome to attend the class, but any person under the age of 16 must be accompanied by adults.

id: Anyone Can Draw - Structural - Mornings-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Anyone Can Draw - Structural - Mornings
venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
description:
In this 8 week morning course you will examine structural drawing with a careful helpful approach, focusing on simple perspective drawing and the value of geometric shapes and solids. Both these structural approaches contribute greatly to the success of your drawing.

Geometric shapes can simplifying a subject, unify a drawing and make compositions dynamic. Geometric solids will help render any subject in three dimensions and transition to perspective.

A good working knowledge of the concepts of perspective will help you draw any subject with correct dimensionality. It can also help in your realist drawing, painting and invented subjects and environments. These concepts are also used in most two dimensional art because it enables us to realise great spatial effects, making it an invaluable tool to add to your skill set.

id: Mamma Mia!-St James Theatre, 77-87 Courtenay Place, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Mamma Mia!
venue: St James Theatre, 77-87 Courtenay Place, Wellington
description:
Get ready to say “I Do, I Do, I Do, I Do, I Do!” to the smash-hit jukebox musical based on the songs of Swedish super-group ABBA.

This sunny, funny, international phenomenon unfolds on a Greek island paradise when, on the eve of her wedding, a young woman’s quest to discover the identity of her father brings three men from her mother's past back to the island they last visited 20 years ago.

With music & lyrics by Benny Andersson & Björn Ulvaeus, Mamma Mia! is written by Catherine Johnson and features non-stop laughs and explosive dance numbers, set to ABBA's hit songs including Super Trouper, Dancing Queen, Knowing Me, Knowing You; Take a Chance on Me, Thank You for the Music, Money, Money, Money; The Winner Takes It All and SOS.

Over 70 million people all around the world have fallen in love with the characters, the story and timeless music that makes Mamma Mia! the ultimate feel-good show. It’s been translated into 16 different languages and in 2011 it became the first Western musical ever to be staged in Mandarin in the People’s Republic of China. MAMMA MIA! became the 8th longest running show in Broadway history where it played a record-breaking run for 14 years.

id: The Mars Blueberry Astrobiology Dome-Martinborough Town Hall, 8 Texas St, Martinborough-Event Finder
name: The Mars Blueberry Astrobiology Dome
venue: Martinborough Town Hall, 8 Texas St, Martinborough
description:
The Mars Blueberry Astrobiology Dome is New Zealand's one-of-a-kind portable planetarium experience. It's round, it's blue, and inside it, your mini astronauts will learn about planets, galaxies, the origin of life, and whether aliens are out there.
Most importantly, they get to ask questions to real space scientists! Hari is an astrobiologist who interned at NASA and is a Mars researcher, and Sam is an astrophysicist. They both love answering questions about space and looking at the stars at night with really large telescopes (make sure you check their Star Safari experience too).

Hari and Sam have logged an impressive over 200 school and event visits with the Mars Blueberry since they started in 2022 and have hosted more than 38,000 people through the airlock of the Blueberry.

Each session is a 20-minute live voyage through the universe. No scripts, no recordings – just real science, real stories, and your real questions.
Please note: Children must be accompanied by an adult at all times.

id: Negotiation Skills for Successful Outcomes-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Negotiation Skills for Successful Outcomes
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Everyone negotiates—at work, at home, or anywhere in between. Whether you're closing deals or resolving conflicts, learn how to get what you want and bring others on board with your vision. (NZ citizens and residents free with ID, others pay $100).

Description
Negotiation Skills for Successful Outcomes

What’s the Goal?
To arm you with the strategies, skills, and mindset to walk into any negotiation and leave with the outcome you desire.

What You'll Discover:

Crack the Code on People: Spot different types of negotiators and tailor your approach using the DISC methodology.
Gear Up for Success: Build a killer prep list with intel on your opponent and a clear inventory of your strengths.
Own the Room: Master the art of negotiation strategy, use space to your advantage, and know the unspoken rules.
Discover Your Edge: Tap into your natural negotiation style and make it work for you.
Learn from the Masters: Unlock game-changing tips and theories from the biggest “gurus” in the field.
Practice Makes Perfect: Get hands-on with exercises that turn theory into action.
Ready to negotiate like a pro? This workshop will show you how to make your case, win people over, and seal the deal.

You must be a NZ citizen or resident to register in this course for free and you must provide photo ID when you attend.

description: Ngaio Repair Café, organised in and by Ngaio Union Church, is part of the worldwide Repair Café movement to cut down waste and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. description:

Course costs include basic materials for the process, but do not include the eventual metal costs for the pieces you choose to cast. description:
You should be dancing when the disco era comes alive on stage in Wellington.

You’re invited to put on your boogie shoes and salute the Bee Gees album ‘Saturday Night Fever’. Released in 1977, the album defined a disco generation. Tribute act Best of the Bee Gees Saturday Night Fever and the George Ellis Orchestra come to The Opera House in August 2025. They’ll play chart-busters from that album plus songs from other bands from the 70s like K.C. & The Sunshine Band, and The Trammps. Special guests Debora McLane (niece of the Bee Gees) and Roslyn Loxton join the tribute band on stage.

In a two-act orchestrated performance, you’ll hear some of the best songs written by the Gibb brothers. Groove along to tracks like You Should Be Dancing, Stayin’ Alive, Jive Talkin’, Disco Inferno, More Than A Woman, Warm Ride, and so much more.

The album ‘Saturday Night Fever’ was the biggest-selling sound recording between 1977 and 1980. It was awarded Album of the Year at the 1979 Grammys and stayed in the Top 200 for 29 consecutive months. It made Barry Gibb the first solo songwriter in history to have three consecutive number ones, and four songs in the top ten simultaneously.

id: The Joy of Improvisation-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder

venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Discover your creative potential and enjoy improvising scenes and stories in a safe, positive group environment with the Wellington Improvisation Troupe [WIT].

Description
Improv is theatre without a script and a fun way to build your skills in many areas, including team work, public speaking, storytelling and on-your-feet creative thinking.

This is the perfect place for absolute beginners to get acquainted with the joy and art of improvisation, inspired by the generous creative philosophy of Keith Johnstone. It's also a great place to get back into improv if you've been away from it for a while.

WIT has been teaching this course in association with the CEC for almost 20 years now. It uses fun games and structured exercises to teach the foundation skills of improv. These are a prerequisite for further courses and membership of WIT (www.wit.org.nz), as well as useful in themselves.

If you have questions about the course, please contact WIT directly on info@wit.org.nz.

By the end of the course, you'll have:

- Explored basic principles of improvisation
- Enjoyed interacting in a friendly, positive and supportive environment
- Developed more confidence, presentation and communication skills
- Experienced joyful moments of improvisation

The course will end with a directed demonstration of class exercises for invited friends and family.

id: Retirement Reinvented-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Retirement Reinvented
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Whether you’re already retired, or planning ahead, this practical workshop will help you to reflect, re-envision and re-vitalise your life and develop a plan for your future, on your own terms. (NZ citizen and residents free with ID, all others pay $109).

In your middle years, working, retired or somewhere in between? What’s next? Life is about much more than work or leisure, but most of us have given little thought to what “retirement” might mean.

It’s difficult to speculate what may happen in the future – but we can be proactive and take control.
This course offers insights into how to make the most of our time once we’re less focused on career and/or childrearing. It covers many of the issues people face when considering a move from current employment to a different lifestyle that includes more time to do the things we’ve always promised ourselves we’d do – “when we retire”.

After the workshop, you’ll be able to identify a number of common issues and potential ways to manage them when considering and planning your “rejuvenation”, rather than a retirement. We won’t cover financial planning, but will focus on some of the personal growth opportunities for living and making a conscious contribution to your community.

By the end of the day, you’ll have:
- Developed your own perspective on ageing and retirement in the 21st Century and identified what’s important to you
- Completed a personal life audit exercise and considered your strengths
- Explored possibilities in the major aspects of your life and identified potential challenges and strategies for overcoming them
- Developed a blueprint to maximise the best years of your life and developed a “future proofing” downsizing plan
- Considered options to include a sense of purpose and explored and implemented choices that provide you with that sense of purpose
Bring a pen and paper.

1 day, Sat 9:30 AM – 4:00 PM
Wellington High School
Presented by Angela Robertson

id: On a Good Day - EP Launch - Hihi & The Stitchbirds-Moon, 167 Riddiford Street, Wellington-Event Finder
name: On a Good Day - EP Launch - Hihi & The Stitchbirds
venue: Moon, 167 Riddiford Street, Wellington
description:
Come celebrate Hihi & The Stitchbirds' first EP - On a Good Day - an exploration of love, and loss, and the pieces in between.

7:00pm - Doors

7:30pm - The Bidibids

8:30pm - Hihi & The Stitchbirds

After a whirlwind 18 months as a five-piece folk band, Hihi & The Stitchbirds are delighted to release their debut EP with five original songs that will make you feel soothed and seen. Written by band members Tess Luff, Elena Saunders and Ellie Stewart, this group of talented musicians invite you into contemplative corners of their brains with a set of gentle and jovial numbers that will entertain and delight.

They will be joined on stage by their friends the Bidibids.


About Hihi & The Stitchbirds:

Hihi & The Stitchbirds are an exciting five-piece musical experiment, based in Te Whanganui-a-Tara. Pairing rich vocal harmonies with vibrant original music inspired by the folk and Americana playbooks, this band brings something for everyone.

Hihi & The Stitchbirds are:


Elena Saunders - vocals and vibes

Chris Goldsbury - guitar, clarinet and vocals

Tess Luff - guitar, banjo uke and vocals

Matt Hutton - bass uke and vocals

Ellie Stewart - fiddle and vocals


About the Bidibids:

With lush harmonies, intricate arrangements, and beguiling melodies, the Bidibids explore what it means to play folk music in New Zealand. The Bidibids are Sarah August on banjo and guitar, Simon Carryer on cello-banjo, and Brendan Schenk on mandolin and guitar. The trio came together at the 2020 Wellington Folk Festival, where they were each supposed to be playing in different groups. Since then, the Wellington-based band have become regulars at some of the region’s best venues for folk music, including the Mussel Inn, Moon, and the Wellington Bluegrass Society.

Driven by Sarah’s honest, intimate songwriting and Brendan’s blazing musicianship, the Bidibids balance soulful ballads that will tug your heart-strings with upbeat numbers which will get your toes tapping. Influenced by American bluegrass and folk bands like Watchhouse and Nickel Creek, they’re also inspired by local acts like the Eastern and Marlon Williams who are forging an authentic New Zealand folk tradition. You can listen to the Bidibids' debut EP here: https://open.spotify.com/album/6Q8HW5g0FzDl3VYz44OZU5?si=4gIRmfaRSiOUlgxJnVUbuw.

After a massive summer of festivals and touring alongside L.A.B across Aotearoa and Australia, Corrella are hitting the road this August for their biggest headline tour yet — bringing their new album Skeletons to the stage for the very first time.

Skeletons marks the next chapter for the band as they continue to cement their place in the New Zealand and Australian music scenes. The album follows their breakout debut Road From 26, which featured the sleeper hit Blue Eyed Māori—a track that now holds the record for the most weeks ever spent at Number One on the NZ Singles Chart.

Since their debut, Corrella have sold out shows nationwide, become festival favourites, and picked up multiple Aotearoa Music Awards and Waiata Māori Music Awards.
This run of shows will be their biggest headline tour to date. See Corrella live as they hit the road in August for their Skeletons Winter Tour taking on Auckland's Tuning Fork, Hamilton’s Factory, Wellington’s San Fran, Christchurch’s The Church & Dunedin’s Erricks, presented by Loop. id: Qi Gong-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Qi Gong
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Qi gong, pronounced “chi gong,” was developed in China thousands of years ago as part of traditional Chinese medicine. It involves using exercises to optimize energy within the body, mind, and spirit, with the goal of improving and maintaining health and well-being.

Qigong has both psychological and physical components and involves the regulation of the mind, breath, and body’s movement and posture.

In most forms of qigong:

Breath is slow, long, and deep. Breath patterns may switch from abdominal breathing to breathing combined with speech sounds.
Movements are typically gentle and smooth, aimed for relaxation.
Mind regulation includes focusing one’s attention and visualization.
Dynamic (active) qigong techniques primarily focus on body movements, especially movements of the whole body or arms and legs. Meditative (passive) qigong techniques can be practiced in any posture that can be maintained over time and involve breath and mind exercises, with almost no body movement.
Wear loose, comfortable clothing and bring a bottle of water.

[This is a physical activity that involves an element of risk. While all possible measures are taken to prevent accidents or injury, please note that participation is at your own risk].

id: The Magic of Her Body: Readings of Katherine Mansfield's Queer Writing-Katherine Mansfield House & Garden, 25 Tinakori Rd, Thorndon, Wellington-Event Finder
name: The Magic of Her Body: Readings of Katherine Mansfield's Queer Writing
venue: Katherine Mansfield House & Garden, 25 Tinakori Rd, Thorndon, Wellington
description:
Back after a sold-out season during the 2025 Wellington Pride Festival!

Heritage New Zealand Pouhere Taonga, Katherine Mansfield House & Garden, and Vixen Temple present The Magic of Her Body: Readings of Katherine Mansfield’s Queer Writing, an immersive theatrical experience in one of Aotearoa’s leading historic house museums.

Join performance artist Vixen Temple and historian Kerryn Pollock of Heritage New Zealand Pouhere Taonga on a journey through Mansfield’s sensual diary entries and sapphic-coded short stories, moving through the rooms in the home of her birth, Katherine Mansfield House & Garden in Thorndon. Live musical accompaniment will be performed by Ms Weeds.

The Wednesday performance will be followed by a Q&A session.

Katherine Mansfield (1888-1923) is one of Aotearoa’s most internationally acclaimed writers. Born in Wellington, she lived permanently in England and Europe from 1908 until her untimely death from tuberculosis in 1923. She became a central figure in literary modernism alongside contemporaries such as Virginia Woolf and DH Lawrence. In the words of biographer Gill Boddy, ‘She sought to capture the transitory vividness of life and to bring ordinary moments and people into focus so that their full significance could be understood’. Her passionate diary entries, beginning when she was a teenager, reveal a sapphic sensibility and identity that carried over into her fiction. Mansfield is a messy, relatable teen, a literary diva, and queer icon whose voice speaks to us beyond time.

"The evening’s structure flows beautifully: a mix of Mansfield’s writings, historical insights, and Temple’s magnetic performance. She holds the audience in the palm of her hand—drawing laughter, gasps and breathless silence at all the right moments." - Theatreview

"Thank you for weaving together history, performance, place, music and queer pride into such a special, moving, beautiful experience. There’s nothing like it, it was unforgettable." - Audience feedback

Please note: Katherine Mansfield House & Garden is a modestly-sized historic house. This event will take place throughout the house and most audience members will need to stand for the duration of the show. Unfortunately, the house is not wheelchair accessible and we do not have an accessible bathroom.

id: Ghost Trio (piano trio)-St Andrews on the Terrace, 30 The Terrace, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Ghost Trio (piano trio)
venue: St Andrews on the Terrace, 30 The Terrace, Wellington
description:
Monique Lapins (violin), Ken Ichinose (cello) and Gabriela Glapska (piano).

The programme is titled “Between Tides” based upon the concept of a journey through time and cultural landscapes, showcasing the evolution of chamber music from the late 18th century (Beethoven) to the 20th century (Shostakovich), and finally to the contemporary era (Takemitsu, Downie). Each piece offers a distinct musical experience, reflecting the stylistic diversity and cultural richness of classical music through the lens of the piano trio. There is a world premiere of a work by New Zealand’s own Glen Downie, written especially for the Ghost Trio.

Ludwig van Beethoven, Piano Trio in D major Op 70 No. 1 “Ghost”
Tōru Takemitsu, Between Tides SJ1091
Glen Downie, Sonata da chiesa (world premiere) (Aotearoa, 1991)
Dmitri Shostakovich, Piano Trio No. 2 in E minor Op 67

id: Immersive Yoga: We Are Nature-Bhakti Lounge Wellington, 1st Floor, 175 Vivian Street, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Immersive Yoga: We Are Nature
venue: Bhakti Lounge Wellington, 1st Floor, 175 Vivian Street, Wellington
description:
A one-of-a-kind yoga experience designed to awaken the senses, stir reflection, and bring you into deeper connection — followed by a nourishing plant-based dinner and dessert.

Take this moment to become grounded in your true nature through embodied movement. This practice is your invitation to appreciate and develop a deeper connection with the Earth — to slow down, to notice the changing landscapes and seasons around you, and to find them within you. It’s a chance to remember that we are part of this world, shaped by the same rhythms, held by the same ground.

We speak of “getting into nature” as something we have to do — yet Earth-based traditions have always seen the plant and all beings as interconnected and sacred, humans as one with the Earth itself.

This is more than a yoga class — it’s an immersive experience designed to bring you back into that sense of belonging.

As you move through gentle hatha yoga, you’ll be surrounded by breathtaking visuals of our earthly home, designed and projected by Andy from Hype Entertainment. The space will come alive with images of nature from sunset to sunrise — each scene offering a distinct atmosphere to reflect and move with. A curated soundscape and subtle aromatherapy will support your journey, drawing you deeper into the moment.

Let us weave the scared back in, to weave nature back into the centre of our everyday lives. Let us find our way back through nature, to our true nature and selves.

After your practice, stay to enjoy a wholesome plant-based dinner and dessert, included in your ticket.

Meet Nicola, your teacher
With over 20 years of teaching experience and a deep connection to yoga philosophy, Nicola’s gentle guidance will lead you on a journey of self-discovery. Her classes are a blend of warmth and wisdom, helping you explore both your body and your spirit. As a teacher, she embraces the essence of yoga in every aspect of her life, creating a space where you can experience not only physical movement but a true connection to your inner self.

description:
Everyone negotiates—at work, at home, or anywhere in between. Whether you're closing deals or resolving conflicts, learn how to get what you want and bring others on board with your vision. (NZ citizens and residents free with ID, others pay $100).

Description
Negotiation Skills for Successful Outcomes

What’s the Goal?
To arm you with the strategies, skills, and mindset to walk into any negotiation and leave with the outcome you desire.

What You'll Discover:

Crack the Code on People: Spot different types of negotiators and tailor your approach using the DISC methodology.
Gear Up for Success: Build a killer prep list with intel on your opponent and a clear inventory of your strengths.
Own the Room: Master the art of negotiation strategy, use space to your advantage, and know the unspoken rules.

Practice Makes Perfect: Get hands-on with exercises that turn theory into action.
Ready to negotiate like a pro? This workshop will show you how to make your case, win people over, and seal the deal.

id: Retirement Reinvented-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Retirement Reinvented
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Whether you’re already retired, or planning ahead, this practical workshop will help you to reflect, re-envision and re-vitalise your life and develop a plan for your future, on your own terms. (NZ citizen and residents free with ID, all others pay $109).

In your middle years, working, retired or somewhere in between? What’s next? Life is about much more than work or leisure, but most of us have given little thought to what “retirement” might mean.

It’s difficult to speculate what may happen in the future – but we can be proactive and take control.
This course offers insights into how to make the most of our time once we’re less focused on career and/or childrearing. It covers many of the issues people face when considering a move from current employment to a different lifestyle that includes more time to do the things we’ve always promised ourselves we’d do – “when we retire”.

After the workshop, you’ll be able to identify a number of common issues and potential ways to manage them when considering and planning your “rejuvenation”, rather than a retirement. We won’t cover financial planning, but will focus on some of the personal growth opportunities for living and making a conscious contribution to your community.

By the end of the day, you’ll have:
- Developed your own perspective on ageing and retirement in the 21st Century and identified what’s important to you
- Completed a personal life audit exercise and considered your strengths
- Explored possibilities in the major aspects of your life and identified potential challenges and strategies for overcoming them
- Developed a blueprint to maximise the best years of your life and developed a “future proofing” downsizing plan
- Considered options to include a sense of purpose and explored and implemented choices that provide you with that sense of purpose
Bring a pen and paper.

1 day, Sat 9:30 AM – 4:00 PM
Wellington High School
Presented by Angela Robertson

id: Jewellery Making-Soldered Fidget Rings-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Jewellery Making-Soldered Fidget Rings
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Classic textured rings, with a unique and exciting twist! Learn to make your own fine jewellery fidget rings from copper, brass and silver - beginners welcome! All materials included in course fee.

Description
In this one-day workshop you are offered a hands-on opportunity to create custom rings with fun mobile components and unique textures. We'll also practice and build experience in the essential jeweller’s fabrication skills of sawing, filing, soldering, sanding and polishing.

What are fidget rings? Also known as spinner rings or stim rings, fidget rings have loose bands attached that can move and swivel around - it's interactive sculpture you can wear!

In this course you’ll be lead through the design and creation of custom copper and silver rings, with copper, brass and silver wire spinner bands adding novelty and movement to a classic ring design.

This course offers beginners a fun introduction to jewellery making, and for those with some jewellery experience, it offers a great way to advance and expand your making techniques to new levels.

All materials included in course fee.

Please wear closed-in footwear suitable for a workshop environment. bring a work apron if you have one or wear clothes you don’t mind getting a little grubby. Remember to bring your reading glasses if a have them.

id: Sculpture - Intro to Creature Sculpting-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Sculpture - Intro to Creature Sculpting
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Join us in an exciting new introduction to creative sculpting - a hands on class to produce unique creature figurines and miniatures to bring your imagination to life! - Beginners welcome! All material costs included in course fee.

Description
Whether you want to make creatures cute, creepy, in the style of pop-toys, figurines, or a one-of-a-kind character in your own style, this is the class for you!

Working with air dry clays, oven bake polymer clays and wire, armatures this workshop offers a variety of modelling methods and approaches - a great opportunity to turn ideas into tangible 3D forms. With modern clays we can create translucent, flexible, and even glow-in-the-dark elements to add more realism or a touch of the surreal into each creation!

We’ll kick off working with traditional air-dry clay to get a feel for modelling a few simple forms.

Once familiar with the materials, we’ll go through some basic design elements, guided by animal anatomy and morphology. From here the tutor will show and chat with the group about ways we can transform the creatures from our imagination into unique sculptures full of character.

Students will be coached through designing and creating a series of small-scale creature sculptures, beginning simple, and building to a more complex final form as we gather practice.

The class offers beginner students a fun introduction to sculpting organic forms from scratch, and for those with some hands-on creative experience, it offers a great opportunity to experiment, hone and advance your making skills to new levels.

Please wear closed-in footwear suitable for a workshop environment. bring a work apron if you have one or wear clothes you don’t mind getting a little grubby. Remember to bring your reading glasses if a have them.

id: Delaney Davidson - Anniversary Tour-St Peters Village Hall, Cnr Beach Rd and Ames St, Paekākāriki-Event Finder
name: Delaney Davidson - Anniversary Tour
venue: St Peters Village Hall, Cnr Beach Rd and Ames St, Paekākāriki
description:
With multiple album Anniversaries this year, Delaney Davidson takes to the road in July to celebrate his extensive and star studded catalogue with special band The Anniversaries.

15 years ago, Delaney Davidson joined Reverend Beat Man - cult figure, gospel trash preacher, and founder of the hugely influential Swiss record label VOODOO RHYTHM RECORDS, to release “Self Decapitation” and a year later “Bad Luck Man”.

Watch the Video “I’m So Depressed” , from the album “Back Luck Man”

For Radio - Download “I’m So Depressed”

Self Decapitation had such hits as Little Heart (Silver Scroll Finalist 2011) and barnstormer Dirty Dozen while Bad Luck Man had You’re a Loser (country music song of the year 2012), aswell as I’m So Depressed, and evergreen Time Has Gone. These albums cemented him into the Voodoo Rhythm Family and saw him become a distinct cult figure of the European Touring circuit.

Generally dealing with the darker side of things, Delaney Davidson has been described as “being the reigning king of capturing the essence of “Noir” in Country and Folk Music, pushing at the framework and preconceptions of roots music with his brand of modern gothic Americana.” (Post to Wire).

Having spent the last 20 years as travelling “troubadour" around the globe, sometimes solo, sometimes with accomplices, but always with his Ghost Orchestra, Delaney Davidson has found new focus embracing a love of Aotearoa.

Through his collaborative work with Troy Kingi “ Black Sea, Golden Ladder”, his visual art work with Tame Iti, and his most current album “Out Of My Head” produced by Merk, he has featured such varied talents as Hayley Westenra and Reb Fountain and has toured with Chamber Music New Zealand - all the while continuing to reinvent concepts and challenge expectations, and gaining respect and admiration from audiences.


"Incontestably one of Aotearoa’s most influential and lauded contemporary songwriters” Under The Radar

Delaney Davidson now takes his band of Anniversaries on the local roads around Aotearoa, don’t miss a night of wry sense of humour, some theatre of unease, and a rocking collection of bangers from his extensive back catalogue as he celebrates the music that got him where he is today.

id: Creative Writing - A Tasting Plate-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Creative Writing - A Tasting Plate
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Get your creativity flowing by exploring some of the star forms of creative writing, focusing each week on a different area of fiction or creative non-fiction.

How often have you said, ‘I wish I could write’? There are many different kinds of writing. Starting is easy so why not give it a go by joining this creative writing ‘tasting plate’.

Each week we’ll focus on a different area of fiction or creative non-fiction. By the end of the programme, you’ll have tried your hand at writing a short story, a narrative poem, a travel memoir, a personal essay drawing from your life, an interview article, a story for children, a short film script and a piece of historical fiction.

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
- Create works of fiction
- Develop creative non-fiction text
- Explore the natural inner spirit of writing
- Discover your unique writer’s voice
- Reflect on your own experiences in writing
- Investigate different writing strategies
- Discover where your personal writing passions sit and what works for you.

Bring pen and paper or a laptop.

This course is designed to help you improve your skills, to develop your unique writer's voice and to encourage you to take risks on the page. It is not a course where you'll be asked to read your work out loud, critique other writers work, or hand in your writing to the tutor. This is a safe place where you will be supported to do what writers do best - write.

name: Sue Dyson - Welcome To Our Lounge
venue: Hilltop, 17 Upland Road, Kelburn, Wellington
description:
Welcome To Our Lounge Tour - Featuring songs from Linda Ronstadt & Carole King
Gate opens 6.30pm Music Starts 7pm Saturday 16 August 2025
Sue Dyson, a gifted vocalist known for her warm and captivating stage presence, backed by talented pianist Mitch Dean to offer an extraordinary musical experience that celebrates the enduring legacies of Linda Ronstadt and Carole King. Set in Hilltop's laid-back intimate atmosphere, their performances promise an engaging experience where the audience will tap their feet to the classics that have defined generations. Sue has graced the stage of New Zealand's 'Good Morning Show' multiple times, showcasing her vocal prowess and musical versatility. Additionally, Sue has lent her voice as a backup vocalist at the prestigious New Zealand Music Awards and has enjoyed significant success with her original country music in Australia.
Mitch Dean complements Sue's voice with his extensive expertise as a guitarist and pianist, cultivated over more than 20 years of performing in diverse musical settings. Notably, he played keys and guitar in the acclaimed Wellington Fleetwood Mac Experience, contributing to their successful tour. Mitch’s deep understanding of music, combined with his skillful instrumentation, enriches the duo's sound and enhances the overall performance.
Together, Sue and Mitch create a harmonious blend of nostalgia and artistry, celebrating the timeless contributions of Ronstadt and King. Their performances promise to be an unforgettable evening of music that not only bridges generations but also stirs the soul, inviting audiences to revel in the rich tapestry of these legendary artists' works. Join them for a memorable experience that resonates long after the final note has been played. 
Not for profit, supporting our dedicated musicians. Suggested donation $30
Teas, Coffee and Snacks provided. You're welcome to bring anything you'd like to eat or drink.
Parking available in the Coupon zones of Upland Rd & Glasgow St free after 6pm weekdays, and free all through the weekends. The Wilson Carpark at the top of the Cable Car charges 24/7.

id: Jewellery Making - Faceted Gemstone Settings-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Jewellery Making - Faceted Gemstone Settings
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
Evolve and advance your jewellery making with beautiful faceted stone setting methods! Create jewellery embedded with precious glittering gems in copper, brass and silver - beginners welcome! All material costs included in the course fee.

Description
In this challenging and exciting workshop students will learn to set glimmering round-cut faceted gemstones into brass, copper and/or silver. Create a stone set jewellery project from a choice of simple earrings, a pendant, or a ring.

Students who have already done a Lost Wax Cast Rings class may bring their cast rings and try their hand at setting stones in those instead of starting a new project.

Students will learn ‘Flush Setting’, a method of embedding gems into the surface of metal without the need for solder or joins. The process is adaptable to a number of jewellery types and styles. Students with prior Flush Setting and soldering experience may advance to other methods and to try their hand at learning ‘Bead Setting’, or a simple form of ‘Prong Setting’.

Students may choose from lab-created Sapphires, Rubies and other high strength stones such as Cubic Zirconia in a range of colours.

The workshop is especially satisfying for the magpie in all of us, adding extra colour and shine to jewellery making.

While both beginners and returning students are welcome in the class, be aware that the tools and techniques require a level of fine motor skills, keen eye for detail, and strong hand control which take some patience, practice and perseverance to get the best results.

Our magnifying headsets, work clamps, and patient tutor will help you along the way.

Please wear closed-in footwear suitable for a workshop environment. bring a work apron if you have one or wear clothes you don’t mind getting a little grubby. Remember to bring your reading glasses if you have them.

By the end of the course, students will be able to:

Develop jewellery making skills with introductory faceted stone setting methods

Create a simple stone set project - either earrings, a pendant, or a ring.

Use Vernier Calipers to measure and calculate metal dimensions

Use files to shape brass, copper and/or silver components

Use a soldering torch to attach metal components such as jump rings

File, sand and polish brass, copper and/or silver creations into finished jewellery

venue: Te Marae, Te Papa Tongarewa, 55 Cable Street, Wellington
description:
Join editor and poet Nick Ascroft as he introduces a crackling selection of New Zealand poets from his edition of the annual online anthology Ōrongohau | Best New Zealand Poems. James Brown, Robin Peace, Simon Sweetman, Stacey Teague, Philomena Johnson, Kiri Piahana-Wong, Zephyr Zhang, and others will read their work, and poems by the late Fleur Adcock, Vincent O’Sullivan, and Paula Harris will also be celebrated in this warm-up to Phantom Billstickers National Poetry Day.

id: Paint and Wine Night in Wellington - The Scream-The Borough, 162/168 Main Road, Tawa, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Paint and Wine Night in Wellington - The Scream
venue: The Borough, 162/168 Main Road, Tawa, Wellington
description:
The concept is simple - take a brush in one hand, a drink in the other and let’s paint a masterpiece!

Join us for a creative night of drinking and painting in the heart of Tawa, Wellington! No previous painting experience necessary. Get your creative juices flowing and your brush strokes going!

Drinks: NO DRINKS are included in the ticket price, but drinks are available for purchase.

Food: A delicious menu will be available to purchase throughout the event.

What is Paintvine?
It’s a fun social painting class where our artists will run you through step-by-step instructions on how to create your very own masterpiece in a fun and relaxed bar setting. Perfect for dates, catching up with mates or for meeting new friends!

We provide all the materials you need (high-quality canvas, acrylic paint, brushes). All you need to bring is your creative spirit (or find some at the bottom of a glass). At the end of the night you will leave with your own painting ready to hang up on your wall.

For tickets, future events, FAQs and more info head to the Paintvine website.

id: Adobe InDesign- Beginners-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Adobe InDesign- Beginners
venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
description:
An introduction to Adobe's page layout and design programme. Good computer skills essential.
This introduction to Adobe's program will cover: setting preferences; understanding the frame-based approach through exploration of frame creation, properties and use; placing and editing text (with styles); placing graphics; defining and applying colour and print considerations.

By the end of the workshop, you'll have been introduced to InDesign. You'll be shown the program and the main features of its desktop, and then be taken through how to create and work with the main publishing items (text and graphics) in order to create your own publication.

You'll be able to:
- Describe the features of InDesign and how to work with them
- Create text frames, connect text frames and format text
- Create shapes and frames and format them
- Import pictures into publications
- Use rulers, guides and the pasteboard to lay out pages
- Finish off, check and then print

Presented by Paul Messervy.

id: Anyone Can Draw - Observational - Morning-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Anyone Can Draw - Observational - Morning
venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
description:
In this day time 8 week cause you will learn to create a realistic drawing from what you see. This introductory class teaches the technical skills of observational drawing using a variety of media, including pen and ink, charcoal, pencil and pastel.

Students will learn a range of formal skills through exercises in the following:


Quality of line

Accurate observation of shape

Gesture drawing

Use of negative and positive shapes

Using tone well


Direct observation of spaces such as interiors, buildings or landscapes
With expert guidance from Denise you will learn a broad range of skills that can serve as a basis for advancing into classes in painting and assist and finding your own means of expression.

All materials provided.

id: InDuna - Go High - EP Release-Moon, 167 Riddiford Street, Wellington-Event Finder
name: InDuna - Go High - EP Release
venue: Moon, 167 Riddiford Street, Wellington
description:
Join Afro-Kiwi artist InDuna to celebrate the release of his brand new EP, ‘Go High’, live at Moon, Wellington on Saturday 2nd August.

‘Go High’ is a gift from InDuna’s younger self to the artist he is today. It's an uplifting and reflective Afro-pop project inspired by his South African roots and journey of resilience. The EP is a reminder to keep dreaming boldly, no matter the obstacles.

Doors open: 9:00 PM
Show starts: 9:30 PM

Venue: Moon, 167 Riddiford Street, Newtown, Wellington
Moon is a wheelchair-accessible venue with both seated and standing options available.

When the NFC ticket bundle is purchased, fans will get exclusive access to a limited edition NFC-enabled EP, featuring the full EP plus unreleased demos and future tracks, delivered directly to your device before they’re available anywhere else. InDuna merchandise will also be available on the night — don’t miss it.

About InDuna:
Self-taught artist and producer InDuna blends Afro-pop with the vibrant spirit of his South African heritage. He was recently honoured with the Young Global Achiever Award at the 2024 Prince’s Trust Awards in London and recognised at Buckingham Palace by King Charles III.

His music has reached global ears, with his track ‘Dreams’, written for the documentary Ink and Gold: An Artist’s Journey to Olympic Glory, winning Best Original Song at the International Online Web Fest and climbing to #6 on the NZ Hot Singles Chart.

id: Discover Te Muna – Explore the Wines-Craggy Range Te Muna Vineyard, 275 Te Muna Rd, Martinborough-Event Finder
name: Discover Te Muna – Explore the Wines
venue: Craggy Range Te Muna Vineyard, 275 Te Muna Rd, Martinborough
description:
Born from passionate vignerons who embrace the challenge of extreme weather conditions, Te Muna Valley’s unique microclimate and soil structure produce exceptional wines with a distinctive style. Join us for an interactive tasting led by wine writer and educator Joelle Thomson, as we explore a curated selection of Te Muna wines from a variety of producers.

You will be picked up from the Square in Martinborough and driven to the stunning Craggy Range Te Muna Estate vineyard, not normally open to the public. Joelle will guide you through a tasting of twelve of Te Muna wines. The experience concludes with a relaxed opportunity to revisit some of your favourites from the tasting and snack on some local products while meeting several of the producers, before being transported back to the Square.

Tickets strictly limited to 16 max people.

id: Te Aro Zero Waste Just Sew Repair Cafe-Te Aro Zero Waste @ Sustainability Trust, 2 Forresters Lane, CBD, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Te Aro Zero Waste Just Sew Repair Cafe
venue: Te Aro Zero Waste @ Sustainability Trust, 2 Forresters Lane, CBD, Wellington
description:
Book online and come along to our August Just Sew session for 2025.

Repairing rather than buying new is a great way to take climate action in your own life – and learn new skills along the way.

Book below and bring along 1-2 clothing or lightweight household items (cushion covers etc) for repair – all needles, thread, and sewing machines will be supplied. We will supply a selection of patches and buttons, but you are also welcome to bring your own if you have something specific in mind.

Our skilled volunteers will be here to assist you with repairs such as missing buttons, tears, holes and hemming. There will also be a DIY table for those who are confident at sewing alone but may not have access to a machine at home.

Please note: this is a repair focused session, not for restyling, embellishing, or creative alterations.

The afternoon is split into three one hour sessions (1-2 pm, 2-3 pm, 3- 4 pm) with 8-10 spots in each - please arrive ON the hour of the session you book.

At times, there may be a small waiting time, we invite you to bring your favourite book, check out the Zero Waste Centre or meet a new friend while you enjoy some light refreshments.

Due to time constraints please only bring 1-2 items for repair so we can ensure everyone’s items have the opportunity to be fixed.

These workshops are made possible thanks to funding from Wellington City Council, Nikau Foundation and support from Repair Café Aotearoa NZ and Repair Café International.

id: Taoism: How to Eat Wisely-Bhakti Lounge Wellington, 1st Floor, 175 Vivian Street, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Taoism: How to Eat Wisely
venue: Bhakti Lounge Wellington, 1st Floor, 175 Vivian Street, Wellington
description:
Discover the ancient wisdom of food, energy, and balance in this insightful session with Dr. Jinfeng — plus enjoy a nourishing plant-based dinner and dessert, included with your ticket.

Many people believe they’re eating healthily, yet still experience fatigue, inflammation, and discomfort. Why is that?

From a Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) perspective, health isn’t just about what you eat — it’s also about when you eat, the energetic nature of the food, and how well it suits your unique body type. In this workshop, you’ll explore food as medicine and gain insight into how to eat in a way that restores vitality, supports digestion, and balances your energy naturally.

What you’ll learn
– The energetic qualities of different foods
– How to identify which foods suit your constitution best
– The ideal times to eat during the day and why timing matters
– How TCM views food as fuel for both physical health and life force

Whether you're curious about Eastern approaches to wellness or looking for practical tools to support your health, this workshop will offer a fresh and meaningful perspective on your relationship with food.

Meet Jinfeng, your host
As a scholarly well-being practitioner with a long history of family heritage (great grandfather and father), Dr. Jinfeng has been practicing Taoist Qigong and Buddhism Great Awakening Zen Meditation to sharpen her own sense and boost her own physical vitality.

Live storytelling is an artform unto itself, requiring different skills and techniques from standup comedy or prose writing. In this four-part workshop, you’ll learn:

- Creative writing exercises and daily practices to to find meaningful stories from your life

id: Bridget Douglas and Michael Tsalka - Flute and Piano-St Andrews on the Terrace, 30 The Terrace, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Bridget Douglas and Michael Tsalka - Flute and Piano
venue: St Andrews on the Terrace, 30 The Terrace, Wellington
description:
Join us for a lunchtime recital of music for flute and piano, featuring works that span the Baroque to the contemporary. The program opens with J.S. Bach’s masterful Flute Sonata in B minor, a cornerstone of the flute repertoire. Internationally renowned visiting pianist, Michael Tsalka, showcases two solo works for piano: Pauline Viardot-Garcia’s charming Sérénade and Gavotte, followed by the World Premiere of Two Poems, One Meditation by British composer Prof. Nicholas Smith. The recital concludes with Schubert’s virtuosic and deeply expressive Introduction and Variations on “Trockne Blumen”, a dramatic tour de force for both flute and piano.

Michael Tsalka is currently serving as a Professor and a Doctoral Supervisor at the School of Music, Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen. He is also a member of the European Academy of Sciences and Arts (EASA), Salzburg, Austria, The Chairman of the Board (and faculty) of the European Fortepiano Museum and Academy (EFM) in Germany. As a pianist and early keyboard performer, he has won numerous prizes in Europe, Asia, North America, and Latin America. He is a versatile musician, who performs repertoire from the early Baroque era to our days. Dr. Tsalka maintains a busy concert schedule, performing circa 100 concerts a year worldwide. Together with musicologist Dr. Angélica Minero Escobar, he has prepared a critical edition of Daniel Gottlob Türk's 30 keyboard sonatas for Artaria Editions in New Zealand. Additionally, ten of his scholarly articles have been published by music journals, in Italy, the U.S.A., and the Netherlands.

He has recorded 40 critically acclaimed CDs, with repertoire from the Baroque period to the Contemporary Era (including many world premiere recordings) for NAXOS, Grand Piano, Paladino, Brilliant Classics, IMI, Sheva Collection, Wirripang, Tempus Clasico, and Ljud & Bild. Circa 85 contemporary compositions (which he premiered) were dedicated to him by composers from all over the world.

Bridget is Section Principal Flute of the NZSO and an Artist Teacher in Flute at the New Zealand School of Music - Te Kōkī. She collaborates on diverse performance projects with a wide variety of local and international musicians throughout Australasia. Bridget particularly enjoys playing chamber music with her musical friends and is regularly featured on Radio NZ Concert.

Bridget has released five albums, four of which were finalists for Best Classical Album at the Aotearoa Music Awards. She encourages the next generation of musicians in Aotearoa through teaching and mentoring at universities and schools nationwide. In 2020 she was awarded the CANZ (Composers Association of NZ) Citation for Services to NZ Music.

id: Italian Film Festival 2025-Regent 3 Cinemas, 230 Queen Street, Masterton-Event Finder
name: Italian Film Festival 2025
venue: Regent 3 Cinemas, 230 Queen Street, Masterton
description:
The Italian Film Festival NZ returns to Masterton’s Regent 3 Cinema, bringing two glorious weeks of passion, laughter, romance, and cinematic brilliance to the big screen from 14 to 27 July 2025.

Now celebrating its 10th spectacular year, the festival showcases the very best of contemporary and classic Italian cinema — from timeless masterpieces to exciting new voices. Whether you're a seasoned Italophile or just in need of a winter escape, this is your ticket to La Dolce Vita.

Opening Night – Monday 14 July, 6.30pm
Join us for GLORIA!, a bold and joyful story of rebellious young musicians reimagining classical music. Your $25 ticket includes a celebratory drink — Peroni, San Pellegrino, or a glass of sparkling Poderi Crisci Pinot Grigio — plus popcorn to keep things cinematic.

Festival Highlights Include:

The heartwarming classic Il Postino
The stylish thriller The Talented Mr. Ripley
The sweeping romance The English Patient
Paolo Sorrentino’s lush and poetic Parthenope
The thought-provoking drama Vermiglio
A moving tribute to a revolutionary woman in Maria Montessori

Artistic Director Paolo Rotondo and Festival Manager Renee Mark will be in Masterton to introduce this year’s programme to share their love of Italian storytelling. Paolo send this message:

“I am thrilled to bring some of the magic of Italian cinema to Masterton—in person. We wish to share with you a celebration of Italy's storytelling, passion, and rich cultural heritage. We have curated films for you to laugh, reflect, and fall in love with the artistry of our filmmakers. In the middle of a Wairarapa winter, I think you will enjoy an escape to the sun of Italia. I can’t wait to share these unforgettable stories with you. Ci vediamo al cinema.”

Don’t miss this magical midwinter journey through the heart and soul of Italian cinema.

A presto — see you at the movies!

Tickets & full programme: www.regent3.co.nz

id: Tony Lyall - Talking....When I Should Be Listening-The Fringe Bar, 26 Allen Street, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Tony Lyall - Talking....When I Should Be Listening
venue: The Fringe Bar, 26 Allen Street, Wellington
description:
Tony is one of New Zealand's best stand up comedians, dealing predominantly in stories.

To make sure he still has stories to tell he has had to put himself into more and more outrageous situations and often during these tense moments Tony thinks to himself, at least I'll get a story out of this. Come to this show to hear what happens when you start talking when you should be listening.

Known for his work on 7 Days, The Project, The ACC Does Game of 2 Halves, Radio Hauraki and multiple NZ International Comedy Festival Galas. He has performed 7 solo hours as part of the NZ International Comedy Festival and at the Melbourne International Comedy Festival. He has also interviewed some of the biggest celebrities on the planet, including Jake Gyllenhaal, Keira Knightley, Ryan Reynolds, Melanie Lynskey, Chris Pratt and the cast of Jackass to name a few. As well as doing all that, he still has time to be a part of the much loved Alternative Commentary Collective.

Tony's MC work has taken him to various sports events around the country. He is the regular Match Day MC for the Black Caps and New Zealand Cricket, and has MCed for both Wellington Cricket and the Blues Rugby Club. He's also a sought after corporate MC and performer, and has entertained some of the biggest companies in New Zealand.

Originally from Blenheim in the South Island, Tony now lives in West Auckland with his wife, three kids and his Toyota Aqua.

id: Unforgettable Dinah Washington: Lisa Tomlins & Wade Reeve Live-Underworld Tavern, 13 Pirie Street, Wellington-Event Finder
name: Unforgettable Dinah Washington: Lisa Tomlins & Wade Reeve Live
venue: Underworld Tavern, 13 Pirie Street, Wellington
description:
A Tribute to the Queen of the Blues

Dinah Washington, the self-proclaimed “Queen of the Blues,” was a powerhouse of jazz, blues, and soul whose voice defined an era. Now, her timeless repertoire is being reimagined by Aotearoa’s own queen of soulful expression—the incomparable Lisa Tomlins.

Lisa’s vocal versatility is legendary. Whether interpreting Tower of Power, jazz standards, or contemporary pop, she brings depth, warmth, and unmistakable style. She’s graced stages with L.A.B., Fly My Pretties, Neil Finn, and countless others—earning her place as one of New Zealand’s most beloved vocalists.

Joining her is the ever-tasteful guitarist Wade Reeve, whose intuitive playing complements Lisa’s voice with elegance and restraint. If you caught their stunning set at CubaDupa, you already know the magic this duo creates.

Maybe you'll hear Dinah’s most iconic songs—What a Diff’rence a Day Made, Cold, Cold Heart, September in the Rain, and of course, Unforgettable. This afternoon promises to be just that.

Capital Blues Members: $10
General Admission: $20
Members also enjoy 10% off at the bar
